comments.commentBody: None of the candidates are qualified to address the questions of how they would handle foreign policy because none of them have before served as POTUS.  Until you sit in the hot seat, you can claim to make all the right calls.  When your decisions affect the lives of millions of people, those decision become a little harder.  There are lots of sideline coaches who've won championships, but very few in practice who do.  At least Bernie is honest enough to admit that he doesn't know.  And I think these candidates have told us how they would handle foreign problems, at least stylistically, which is probably the most important factor.  Can there be any doubt how Donald Trump would handle a foreign policy situation, based on the way he handles problems with his campaign now? I think the same could be said for all the others.  At least with Bernie we can trust he'll handle things on the up and up and look out for the interests of common citizens of all countries.

Since the Clinton administration we have been trying to find effective responses to the difficulties in the middle east, where our national interest is primarily oil. As we move away from fossil fuels, our interest will move away as well. Certain factions within Islam greatly have resented our opportunistic meddling in the region. This is framed as a sort of holy war in response to the actions of the West.

Since 9/11 and the beyond idiotic invasion of Iraq, what have we got for all the resources we have devoted to war? A small group, Al Qaeda, was disrupted. However, its influence spread and morphed around the region into a regional conflict that has toppled governments, displaced and murdered millions, and cost trillions (put terms Americans can relate to.)

All our interventionism has taken a relatively contained problem and turned it in to a humanitarian and international crisis of epic proportion. The unintended consequences have been enormous.

Isis is a fight for control of Islam as were the European conflicts during the Reformation when Catholics murdered Protestants and vice versa. Islam staid out of that.

I agree with Bernie and those foreign policy experts who say we have to act with forethought and with allies to confront the bloodshed and barbarity while looking for ways to calm the situation. Diplomacy is a scalpel; invasion and interventionism is a bludgeon. It patently is ineffective - unless destroying the middle east was the objective. Time for a change.

Henry Kissinger had lots of foreign policy experience.  So is the Times suggesting that he would also be a better president than Sanders? I for one find Clinton's embrace of Kissinger thoroughly disgusting.
Fill In the Foreign Policy Blanks? Someone is going to be filling in for Donald Trump?

All of them including Sanders have a love affair with US military power. Sanders is probably the least bad of the lot. As for Clinton, her great admiration for Henry Kissinger, let alone things that she did as Secretary of State, is more than enough to make people tremble. As for the Republicans go, they are just chaffing at the bit to see what war crimes they will be able to get away with. And as for the Times, we will see what official lies they will publish as fact, no matter who is elected.

Here's some food for thought:

Watch the speeches Hillary gave on women's rights at the 1995 World Conference on Women in Beijing and LGBT rights at the UN Human Rights Council in 2011. Now, imagine Bernie -- or any of the Republican candidates -- doing this. Better yet, ask yourself why none of them did.

Thank you for your much needed words on trying to get the candidates to talk about foreign affairs and specific international problems.  Much of the blame for silence on these subjects is the media's fault in emphasizing the trivial and avoiding substantive policy issues. That's what the candidates wish, because they have no simple, non-complex answers that come close to the truth which any President would have to face.  But, though I'll vote for her, I object to this assertion: " none, other than Hillary Clinton, inspires any confidence in this arena.   No present candidate has had so much to do with the disastrous policy of external regime change in Libya, Syria , Iraq, Iran & the Crimea --mostlybeen bloody, unnecessary and incalculably costly failure.  Note Obama had to change failed policy and with a new Secretary of State, the admirable Kerry, and rightly move in a different direction.  Why don't journalists and pundits ask Clinton not about her Benghazi emails, but about her original support of the Libya debacle in the first place and why she can't embrace and defend the successful pact and detente with Iran?  The media being straight in questioning Clinton on foreign affairs would then have the effect, hopefully, of making the ridiculous generalizations on foreign affairs of the Republicans, topics they'd be made to face.  Following your editorial idea here would make clear the inevitable consequences of sloppy, incorrect decisions about foreign matters.

When I look at most of these comments, I understand how most of these politicians are getting away with complete blather on foreign policy.

By the way, kids, the editoral's point is that at least with Hillary Clinton, you know what you're getting. Don't have to approve, but you know.

The others, good lord.

"The truth is, foreign policy will very likely dominate the next administration, as it has dominated much of the Obama presidency."

You have clearly identified America's core problem: Our administration pays more attention to foreign policy than it does to domestic policy. That is a shame!!!

The United States of America is not the world's "god". Almighty God has many nations on Planet Earth and He is more than capable of taking care of each and every one of them. Where do we get off thinking that if we don't act the world will fall apart? Our nation is falling apart and our leaders are focused on the world. That is a shame!!!

I am not advocating isolationism. We should be engaged in wholesome interaction with other nations; but, we should not think ourselves the rulers, "gods", or guarantors of the world.

It is very clear that vested interests in the USA have co-opted the American media and led it/them to focus the majority of its attention on foreign issues. Our society is suffering but our attention is being focused on foreign issues.

I am not naive enough to suppose that despots, tyrants, dictators and rogue opportunists will not seize occasion to fill power vacuums in certain regions of the world; but, that must not lead us to neglect our own people. Ever since the early 1990's we have been engaged in military action overseas. Twenty five years of war is enough. We need to rebuild our country, heed the needs of our citizens and heal their situations.

Let's hand each of the contenders a map with the names of countries undisclosed. Then have them locate such places as Poland, North Korea, Syria and Georgia using appropriate name tags.  I'd be surprised if some of them placed those countries on the correct continent.  Bonus points given for "less important" nations like Bhutan, Ecuador and Burkina Faso.  In the unlikely event that a tie-breaker is required they can try to determine where Tibet used to be or where Kurdistan might someday be.

replies.commentBody: Your question would be relevant if Hillary had been a good or even average SoS, but she was bad enough to make John Kerry look like a rockstar.

comments.commentBody: How did Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump do when they were Secretary of State?

I am much more interested in what an American President will do in the United States.  I want to hear about investment and fostering solar and wind power, ending oil dependence.  I want to hear about railroads being restored, mass transit systems created, roadways and bridges built and about ending dependence on interstate trucking for goods movement in favor of railroads.  I want to hear that the internal combustion engine is fading into the past.  I'm very much less interested in Assad, the Sunnis and the Shia, the Saudis, etc., but I am interested in the American People.  Yes, we have interests abroad but they should be prioritized in favor of interests at home.

Will Rogers once wrote, "Good judgement comes from experience, and a lot of experience comes because of bad judgement."
How much "experience" would it take for "Know Nothings" like Trump and Cruz to be qualified for the job they seek? Could our country afford the cost of their education? And I omit Rubio only because he has no chance, had he, his misguidance is certainly equal to the ignorance displayed by the other two.

President short_end! What are you going to do about the refugee crisis in Europe??
"Not my problem. here in the US, we're focusing on building our relationships with our important neighbors....Mexico and Canada. We hope to soon include Cuba in NAFTA and have made inroads to also rope in Haiti and Dominican Republic.......these areas are vital to our economy and our national defense!"
But President short_end, what about the war on terrorism? How will you win the war on terrorism??/
"Dont be so scared, you namby-pamby panty waste. The War on Terrorism is a farce, its designed to keep you frightened and under control......We're putting the NSA in a new direction,as they have some very sophisticated and powerful technology that allows us to monitor ALL financial electronic transactions.....and this will help tremendously in our efforts to apply the Federal Tax Code to electronic commerce, including funds transfered between any instution world wide that does business with the US.
this strategy on its own will simply crush any organized terror state that has designs on harming you.....should an act of terror occur anyway....its a violation of US Criminal Code....and rest assured we will hunt down criminals and bring them to justice everywhere on Planet Earth."

It is fair to say that we have a much better idea about Ms. Clinton foreign policy experience compared to the other candidates-----which is precisely why I would never want her anywhere near the White House again.  If more needless war, nation building, regime change, and constant foreign intervention is wanted, she is surely the best pick.
Foreign policy is too complicated for a novice like Trump. His blustering and blathering may get him the nomination but he is completely ignorant to deal with world affairs and crises.

I do know quite enough about HRCs foreign policy views to strongly suspect we will be drawn ever deeper into the Middle-Eastern morass.
You criticize Sanders for not having a "solution" top the ISIS military threat.
Have we seen any "solutions" elsewhere?
Has HRC offered a "solution"?
To date, her experience has led her to foster a foreign policy that has promoted the rise and continuation of ISIS (Libya springs first to mind, but there are plenty of other instances).
I will take Sanders' "judgment" over Clinton's "experience" every single day of the week.

While immigration, particularly from Mexico and Central America, gets a lot of play in the presidential sweepstakes, the candidates themselves have not discussed Mexico, the counry of roughly 110 million people which shares our southern border. In particular, people should be looking at Hillary Clinton's record in Mexico for more confirmation that she can be heavy handed and obtuse in her dealings with it. Her lack of perception was first evident when she visited the Basilica of the Virgin of Guadalupe, asked who painted the image which is traditionally held to be the result of a miracle and later said, "You have a marvellous virgin."
Probably of more significance is her active and extremely strong support of Plan Mérida, It can be strongly argued, that she played a substantial role in the increase in the chaos and violence of the anti-drug activities here. Plan Mérida was originally a three year plan, which has been vastly increased and which. while it contributes to death and destruction in Mexico, certainly aids US military firms in security, information, technology, communications equipment, surveillance aircraft, arms, etc. etc. In 2012, arms sales reached 1.2 billion dollars
Clinton boasts of her travels and contacts around the world, but she appears tone deaf to other cultures and quick on the trigger in more than one place.

replies.commentBody: I think somebody might have just typo'd Ayatollah Khameini, who's a different person from the Ayatollah Khomeini. The confusion is certainly understandable, for obvious reasons, though.
Ha, okay, but watch the broadcast and listen carefully. Cruz mispronounces it. He does not say Khamenei.
I agree with Dave. The transcript was prepared by CNN, not by Cruz. And as much as I dislike Cruz, I think he would be unlikely to make such a glaring mistake.

comments.commentBody:
Memo from the Human Resources Department
RE: Job interviews
The Republican short list is not doing well on qualifications. From last night's debate:
CRUZ: "And I'll tell you, frankly one concern I have with Donald is that although his language is quite incendiary, when you look at his substantive policies on Iran, he has said he would not rip up this Iranian nuclear deal. I think that's a mistake. The Ayatollah Khomeini wants nuclear weapons to murder us." (Source: CNN website - transcript)

Is Ted Cruz referring to the Ayatollah Khomeini who died in 1989?

I think we need to have these people take some tests, such as the Foreign Service Exam, along with tests measuring their contact with reality.

Regards,

Hillary Clinton has no bigger cheer leader than the NYTs.  All this anti-Putin rhetoric which cannot fail to make the world a much more dangerous place.  In Syria Ms. Clinton has tried to undercut President Obama's approach.  Obama's approach is let the CIA handle it which has had poor results.  The Clinton/Panetta course would have been bomb Assad and let the terrorists march into Damascus.  Also to keep 1000s of US troops in Iraq in violation of a treaty with Iraq and totally against the American voters wishes.  The proper course is diplomatic, humanitarian and financial.  ISIS is there because of US intervention in Iraq during Bush's stupid war.  In Libya where Clinton made a fool of herself there was no back up after Qadafi's overthrow.  The Ukrainian mess has been a total Clinton inspired mess with her ally under secretary Nuland.  They have managed to increase Putin's popularity and given their Ukrainian friends a failed state.

World affairs are very complex as this editorial clearly points out, and internal affairs within the U.S. are also very complex. Both areas require a great deal of focus, thought, and discussions with advisers as well as with people who don't agree with you. To think that both internal and foreign affairs today can adequately be handled by one person is foolish. We need a "President" for foreign affairs and a "President" for internal affairs. These 2 people would have to work closely because foreign and internal affairs often overlap.

As an independent who has actually watched the debates and thought about them without partisanship, here is my order of the candidates, best to worst.

1) Sanders.

2) Kasich

3) Rubio

4) Trump

5) Hillary

6) Cruz

No one here has noticed that Trump is the only one who said that he would work for peace between Israel and the Palestinians and mentioned his Jewish grand children as evidence that he is not anti-Israel.

The MAN is not trustworthy, but his policies are among the best.

As Hillary, after having destabilizing Libya, what is her next project? Go to war with Putin? "He is not a nice guy". Sure, but he has nearly 2000 nuclear weapons.

I am afraid Trump would be less dangerous than Hillary.

replies.commentBody: She set them all afire? What disgraceful distortion!

comments.commentBody: Perhaps the reason the candidates talk little about foreign policy is that they all know that Deep State makes those decisions and they have no voice in the matter. You are quite correct about your client Hillary. She has lots of experience: Libya, Syria, Egypt, Ukraine, Yemen, she set them all afire. She'll do likewise with Russia and China if she gets a chance to be the Deep State front woman.

replies.commentBody: Oh, yes, Joe and all you men know that women shouldn't be "hawks".  Of course, when they're not you consider them "weak".  Try again.  It's 2016 - not 1616 - and women are VERY well rounded.
The fiasco of Iraq was a direct result Bush's end-run around Congress and the U.N. No one voted for Gerry Bremer, de-Baathification, and Blackwater.

comments.commentBody: Hillary is a hawk. She talks tough and threatens to send troops to place like Syria where we do not belong. She voted for the Iraq war, which was a fiasco. Our strategy in Afghanistan and Iraq have been to spread money around. This was what the Romans called paying tribute. Except that tribute was paid by the losers. What we should be concentrating on is making the United States energy independent, and we should stop being the world's policeman. The middle east should sort out its own problems. Our deadly military should be used as Teddy Roosevelt advocated: as a big stick to deter aggression, not gasoline poured on a fire.

replies.commentBody: No, It was Gorge W. Bush who destabilized Syria by creating a power vacuum in Iraq, which spread through the Middle East.

comments.commentBody:
"none, other than Hillary Clinton, inspires any confidence in this arena"

Um, wasn't Hillary Clinton the person who destabilized Syria thereby causing a power vacuum, millions dead or homeless and the rise of ISIS?

Dear NYT, it makes me really sad that a major newspaper has abandoned analysis and fairness in favor of partisanship.
